title: 109_hr5612
content: The Act titled "Chattahoochee National Forest Act of 2006" establishes the Mountaintown National Scenic Area within the Chattahoochee National Forest in Georgia. The Mountaintown National Scenic Area is established within the Chattahoochee National Forest in Georgia, consisting of approximately 13,382 acres. The Secretary of Agriculture will submit a final map and boundary description to Congress, with the same force and effect as if included in the Act. The Secretary of Agriculture will submit a final map and boundary description of the Mountaintown National Scenic Area to Congress, with the same force as the Act. The map will be available for public inspection and any discrepancies will be resolved by the map and boundary description required by this subsection. Management of the scenic area will be overseen by the Secretary. The Secretary will manage the Mountaintown National Scenic Area to protect its scenic quality, water resources, and wildlife habitat. In case of discrepancies, the map and boundary description required by this subsection will take precedence. The Mountaintown National Scenic Area will be managed to protect its scenic quality, water resources, and wildlife habitat. This includes managing vegetation for wildlife and fish habitat, developing old-growth forest characteristics, and providing recreation opportunities. In case of conflicts, the management purposes specified will take precedence over general laws and regulations for the National Forest System. The Mountaintown National Scenic Area will be managed to protect scenic quality, water resources, and wildlife habitat. A management plan must be developed within three years, conforming to specified requirements and taking precedence over general laws and regulations. After the enactment of this Act, the Secretary will develop a management plan for the Mountaintown National Scenic Area as an amendment to the Chattahoochee National Forest's land and resource management plan. No new roads will be constructed within the scenic area after the enactment date. After the enactment of this Act, no new roads shall be constructed within the scenic area, except for access to private lands. Timber harvest is prohibited, except for fire control, insect/disease management, public safety, and trail access. The Secretary may conduct vegetation manipulation for wildlife clearings and visual quality maintenance. Firewood can be harvested for personal use. The Secretary may authorize motorized travel within the scenic area for administrative use and wildlife management projects. The scenic area allows motorized travel for administrative use and wildlife management projects. Wildfires will be suppressed to align with management purposes, and insect outbreaks may be controlled to maintain scenic quality and protect private lands. The area will also be administered to preserve water resources. (i) Insects and Disease.--Control insect and disease outbreaks in the scenic area to maintain scenic quality, prevent tree mortality, reduce hazards, and protect private lands. (j) Water.--Administer the scenic area to maintain or enhance existing water quality. (k) Mining Withdrawal.--All federally owned lands in the scenic area are withdrawn from mining laws and leasing claims, subject to valid existing rights. Designation of additional national forest system land as wilderness in Georgia. Designation of approximately 8,448 acres of land in Georgia as wilderness, part of Chattahoochee National Forest. Includes three additions to Southern Nantahala Wilderness: Ben Gap (1,294 acres), Shoal Branch (412 acres), and Tate Branch (1,085 acres). Three additions to Southern Nantahala Wilderness: Ben Gap (1,294 acres), Shoal Branch (412 acres), and Tate Branch (1,085 acres). One addition to Blood Mountain Wilderness: Cedar Mountain (561 acres). Two additions to Brasstown Wilderness: Duck Branch (190 acres) and Wilson Cove (563 acres). One addition to Ellicott Rock Wilderness: Ellicott Rock Addition (562 acres). Two additions to Cohutta Wilderness. The curr_chunk describes various additions to existing wilderness areas, including Duck Branch (190 acres), Wilson Cove (563 acres), Ellicott Rock Addition (562 acres), Foster Branch (165 acres), Ken Mountain (527 acres), Helton Creek (2,451 acres), and Tripp Branch (638 acres). These additions aim to expand the protected wilderness areas. The Helton Creek addition to Tray Mountain Wilderness consists of 2,451 acres, while the Tripp Branch addition is 638 acres. The Secretary will provide final maps and boundary descriptions to Congress for these designated wilderness lands. The Secretary will provide final maps and boundary descriptions for the designated wilderness lands, which will be available for public inspection. The lands will be administered in accordance with the Wilderness Act and this section. The designated wilderness lands will be administered in accordance with the Wilderness Act and this section, with no impact on Georgia's jurisdiction over fish and wildlife. The designated wilderness lands in the Chattahoochee National Forest will not affect Georgia's jurisdiction over fish and wildlife. The Federal land designated as wilderness is withdrawn from various forms of entry and disposal under public land and mining laws. The Federal land designated as wilderness by this Act is withdrawn from all forms of entry, appropriation, or disposal under public land and mining laws.
